Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: High Endurance Power System for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) Using Radiosotopic Power
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to investigate the commercial potential of a developed power system for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) with a high potential impact on military operations and commercial industries. Ultimately, the technology simply produces ultra-long endurance energy, and after proving the safety and reliability of the power system, can be expanded to other industries. For example, the power system could be used in an ultra-long endurance unmanned undersea vehicle, to power a desalination plant, or even just as a power source for buildings. As the miniaturization of the technology improves, the power system could also be used in consumer devices- providing ultra-long endurance power for cell phones, tablets, and laptops.

This I-Corps project is commercializing a power system design that will produce 300W of electric power and weigh under 150 lbs. Detailed studies have supported the feasibility of the design of the power system. The power-to-weight ratio of this power system's design is similar to current unmanned aerial systems having proven flight capability. This comparison also supports the feasibility of the power system being used for powered flight, and potentially increasing UAV endurance to over one year.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Coming into I-Corps, we had a technology that we believed could have a big impact. Furthermore, we believed, albeit naively, that we had determined product-market fit through the limited customer discovery interviews that we had conducted prior to I-Corps. On day one in Austin, TX, however, we quickly learned how our limited customer discovery meant very little and that we proven very little about our technology. 

Initially, we focused on aerial use cases for our technology. Through our 102 interviews, however, while we learned that there was a fit for our technology in aerial use cases, there was an even larger demand and fit for our technology as a ground-based system. This completely changed the trajectory of customer discovery, and in the end resulted in us finding a much stronger product-market fit than we had at the beginning.

I-Corps was most impactful in the fact that it did verify product-market fit for our core technology. Because of this, we have since incorporated a company, raised venture capital funding, and won other government grants. I-Corps also impacted the development of our technology, as it gave us a far better sense to how our customers will use our technology. We were able to make tweaks that made our technology far more compelling to customers, all because of the information we gathered in our customer discovery interviews.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/25/2019
Modified by: Steven L Krahn
